paragraphs.title: Purpose
paragraphs.p: In this activity, we will explore how to transform the graph of a function by making changes to its formula. By the end of this activity, you will be able to

li.p: Write the formula for a basic function which has been transformed.
Sketch the graph of a basic function which has been transformed.

paragraphs.p: You should now see how a function's graph is transformed by changing its formula in the following ways:

In the first case, adding a value k outside of the function produced a vertical shift to the graph. Adding a positive number shifted the graph up, and adding a negative number shifted the graph down. This should make sense because f(x) is the output of the function, so adding a value outside will change the y values.

In the second case, adding a value h inside the function produced a horizontal shift to the graph. Adding a positive number shifted the graph to the left, and adding a negative number shifted the graph to the right. This also makes sense because x is the input of the function, so adding a value inside the parentheses will change the x values.

It may have been surprising to see that adding a positive number to the input will move the graph to the left, but consider this: In the example f(x) = x^2, the vertex is the lowest point, occuring when the input x = 0. For a parabola to be shifted horizontally 5 units to the right, this should happen when the number being squared is 0. So, making the transformation f(x-5) = (x-5)^2 does just that – it forces the value x = 5 to give 0 as the argument in the function f(x) = x^2. So, this moves the vertext over to the value x = 5.

example.p: The function h(t) = -4.9t^2 + 10t + 40 will approximate the height of an object which was thrown straight upward at a speed of 10 at time t = 0 seconds from a height of 40. See the graph below.
You can move the point to see when the object will hit the ground. Notice that this defines the practical domain of the funciton: 0 \leq t \leq 4.05

Now, we can use this function to describe other situations involving such an object. For example, if the person had waited one second to throw the object, then the graph would be shifted horizontally to the right by one second.
To shift the graph to the right, we make the transformation: h(t-1) = -4.9(t-1)^2 + 10(t-1) + 40Notice that this shift changed the domain of the function to: 1 \leq t \leq 5.05

Next, suppose the person waited one second before throwing the object but also took it an additional 12 upward before throwing it. This involves a horizontal shift of 1 to the right and a vertical shift of 12 upward: h(t-1) + 12 \amp= -4.9(t-1)^2 + 10(t-1) + 40 + 12 \amp=-4.9(t-1)^2 + 10(t-1) + 52This also changed the domain of the function, this time to: 1 \leq t \leq 5.43

conclusion.p: Now let's put this information to the test to determine the equation of a function which has been transformed.

exercise.title: Finding a formula from a graph
